reviewText: After letting their beloved "Golden Collection" DVD line end a few years back, Warner Bros is slowly redeeming itself in the eyes of fans with new-to-video collections like this on Blu-ray and DVD.  And let me just say up front that if you are a true fan, Blu-ray is the ONLY way to go here.  Aside from the obvious higher resolution images, the Blu set contains 11 additional mouse-themed cartoons, for a total of 30 shorts.You probably already know if these are the kind of Looney Tunes you like.  There's no Bugs Bunny here, or "the one with the singing frog."  It's just what it says: mouse cartoons, and lots of 'em.  Of course, the collection is also essential for fans of the great Chuck Jones.  We all know that this doesn't quite represent the maverick director's funniest or most inspired work that he would achieve in his later cartoons.  Looney Tunes in general, didn't exactly get, well, looney until the mid-40's anyway.  But Jones was still a great visual storyteller, and even his more generic stuff (Sniffles, I'm looking at YOU), was often still colorful and charming.My only complaint with the set is that the cartoons are not listed on the package, nor are there any helpful liner notes.  TheLooney Tunes Platinum Collection: Volume One (Ultimate Collector's Edition) [Blu-ray] contained a very nice and detailed booklet, listing and describing each short.  I admit this is a minor problem, but as a hardcore fan, I expected a little more in the package.So is the "Mouse Chronicles" essential viewing?  For true LT fans, of course it is.  Casual viewers, however, will probably be bored by some the older, and admittedly less amusing, shorts.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In a way, this feels like an evolution of Charles M. Jones as a director for the insufferable Termite Terrace crew. Chuck was still dabbling with Disney-style pacing while creating the Sniffles cartoons, which permeate all of Disc 1. The shorts rely on beautiful backgrounds and good-natured fun instead of the zany gags found on other works, like Tex Avery's. When 'The Unbearable Bear" came about later on, Sniffles transformed from a cute lil' creature to a blabbermouse for lack of a better term. Sniffles would eventually become retired with "Hush My Mouse" in 1946, one of the last Looney Tunes' to carry that signature Porky Pig ending of "That's All Folks".Disc Two is the Hubie and Bertie series in their entirety. If Sniffles was the "Disney" disc, then this dastardly duo is definitely the WB we know and love. The two discs have a stark contrast of character traits, which taken as a whole, makes this set better than if you individually rate all the cartoons. H+B even have a Oscar-nominee with House Wreckers in the bunch. However, the cartoons with Claude Cat really bring a great study to that table, the hypochondriac has to fend off the hilariously evil H+B. All told, the two series' combined bring in only 19 cartoons, barely enough to warrant a second disc.At least for the BD, there is a selection of un-restored cartoons added. Some of them are good, and some of them are indifferent, and then there's Merlin...ugh. Maurice LaMarche hosts a cool feature of "Of Mice and Pens". Lastly, there's a storyboard for the Hypo-chondri-Cat, which is arguably the best short in this collection. The price point is high, and some people will understandably back away because of the lack of "recognizable" characters. For people who jump in, they will be rewarded with a portfolio of cartoons that really define Chuck Jones as a director. (Last note: Some of the cartoons have original titles restored to the shorts. These credits weren't fully restored, but they don't reflect the quality of the overall animation.)
summary: A niche product most Looney Tunes fans will enjoy.

reviewText: I love "Sniffles"! I have always loved Sniffles! The problem is that  Bugs Bunny represents 80% of what they show on TV. Daffy is another 14% and most of the rest is 5%. Sniffles represents 1% of Looney Tunes and I treasured every single time one appeared. For some time, I've imagined how wonderful it would be to get every single Sniffles cartoon on one DVD. In addition, the second DVD contains all the "Hubie and Bertie" cartoons (which I happen to enjoy as well).  Here's the bottom line, there is no better mouse in cartoon-dom than Sniffles. Don't tell me about "MIC-KEY" or "MIN-NIE". I don't want to hear about Jerry (of "Tom &" fame). "Mighty" is hooked on snuff, "Speedy Gonzales" is too ethnic, "Stuart Little" was ruined with Michael J Fox, "Fievel Mousekewitz"?? Ask a kid who the hell is Fievel Mousekewitz, "Remy" is Pixar and computer generated and is disqualified, "Itchy" (from the Simpsons) - meh - ------ there is nothing better than Sniffles.I LOVE SNIFFLES and he's AVAILABLE on BluRay!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviewText: I have been a fan of the classic Looney Tunes since I was a kid in the 70's. I own all of the gold series boxes,  and still have the old laserdiscs.  I have passed on buying the Blu-Rays so far until they start releasing some of the older ones that have not been put out on DVD.  When I saw that this would include the entire collection of Sniffles cartoons, I had to buy it.  All I can say is WOW!  I have never seen these look so good!  I immediately compared the Blu-Ray and DVD versions of "Sniffles takes a Trip",  and cannot believe the difference.  There is so much more detail in the picture and colors, it's amazing.  It's good to know that they are finally doing justice to the work of those great artists that made these short films. The Blu-Ray also has 11 bonus cartoons that are not included on the DVD set.  Never cared much for the Hubie/Bertie cartoons,  but they look amazing as well..Although I am highly impressed with this release, I will probably still pass on upcoming Blu-Rays unless they offer cartoons that have not been released before.  Come on Warner Bros., do a proper series with EVERYTHING and in chronological order like you did with the Laserdiscs so many years ago.
summary: Sniffles never looked so good - A must buy for fans
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been a long time fan of WB toons.  With the advent of the blu ray disc, I was ever hopeful that WB would do a really nice job on the "restoration" of these cartoons.While the first disc's cartoons look very impressive, WB continues to overcrop the tops and bottoms of the picture in order to present a wider picture on your widescreen television.  As a result, many gags and facial features that occur on the extreme top and bottom of the image are unable to be seen.Furthermore, on more than half of these cartoons, the original title sequences are missing...being replaced by the re-release openings that are called "Blue Ribbon" titles (since they show a blue ribbon after the WB logo).  This is a real shame as the original title sequences include all the production credits and music original to each cartoon.My biggest beef with this two disc set is that the bonus cartoons presented on disc two are all presented in 480p...low definition.  And while it is apparent that no attempt was made to restore any of the bonus cartoons, the fact that they were simply pulled from old masters to help fill out this set is not cool, especially for those of us who really love these cartoons.  So basically you are getting one and a half discs of high definition cartoons and eight low definition cartoons.I hope WB steps it up a little bit as far as quality for the future incarnations of these character specific cartoon sets.
summary: Looney but not a home run

reviewText: Chuck Jones' talent is on display in the mouse chronicles. This snatch and grab from WB divides its time between the annoyingly precocious Sniffles the mouse, and the more fondly recalled Hubie and Bertie comic capers that showcase Jones' unbelievable versatility for sight gags and slapstick.Here's the thing. Warner gives us Sniffles (barely remembered) but continues to ignore Speedy Gonzalez, an infinitely more enduring and endearing 'mouse' in the Looney Tunes pantheon, though regrettably, not as 'politically correct' toward Hispanics. Warner pads out the limited offerings with 19 additional cartoons that have NOT been digitally remastered. Really, I don't see the point. On hi-def these 'bonus' cartoons suffer from severe edge enhancement, color bleeding and excessive video noise. Are we really supposed to be glad WB gave us these extras when they haven't taken the time to offer them at a level of quality we can appreciate?!?Also and extra - of Mice and Pens - too short and little more than a gloss over of the WB animation legacy. Dumb and wasteful. Not recommended!
summary: A money grab 2 disc set at best
Title: N/A

reviewText: First let me say that these are all remastered.  15 are new to DVD, all are new to Blu-rayI never thought I would see a collection of Chuck Jones SNIFFLES cartoons on Blu-ray. They are cute, but not classic.In the early stages of Chuck Jones' directing career he was trying to imitate Walt Disney with heartwarming cute characters.This set doesn't pick up energy until #13 THE ARISTO-CAT (1943) where we meet HUBIE & BERTIE. They are a crack-up! Disc #2 will get more viewing than Disc #1.This set seems more like a combination of two "All Stars" DVDs, the first a set of SNIFFLES cartoons and the second a set of HUBIE & BERTIE CARTOONS.Other than both series being about mice, they are worlds apart in style and humor.  My preference is to HUBIE & BERTIE in disc #2.My guess is that there are too many SNIFFLES cartoons and not enough HUBIE & BERTIE cartoons for individual single disc releases.Episodes:DISC 1 (ALL Sniffles cartoons)Naughty but Mice (1939)  *with original titles** commentary by Jerry BeckLittle Brother Rat (1939)  **With RESTORED TITLES***Sniffles and the Bookworm (1939)Sniffles Takes a Trip (1940) (also on LT Golden Collection 3 DVD)The Egg Collector (1940)Bedtime for Sniffles (1940)Sniffles Bells the Cat (1941)Toy Trouble (1941)The Brave Little Bat (1941)The Unbearable Bear (1943)Lost and Foundling (1944)Hush my Mouse (1946)  **With RESTORED TITLES***DISC 2 (ALL Hubie & Bertie, who seem to switch their colors half way through the run.)The Aristo-Cat (1943) - Meadows the butler is fed up with Pussy and leaves, so H&B; take over. (also on the Golden Collection 4 DVD)Trap Happy Porky (1945) - Porky Pig, at the Uncle Tom's Cabin Lodge, is kept awake by two noisy mice.  ***With RESTORED TITLES***Roughly Squeaking (1946) - Hubie & Bertie convince a goofy cat that he is a lion.House Hunting Mice (1948) - Hubie & Bertie invade the "House Of Tomorrow" and terrorize the automatic sweeper.Mouse Wreckers (1949) - Hubie & Bertie mess with Claude Cat as he is sleeping, convincing him that he is having nightmares.The Hypo-Chondri-Cat (1950)  - Hubie & Bertie terrorize Hypochondriac Claude Cat.  (also on the Golden Collection 1 DVD) now ***With RESTORED TITLES***Cheese Chasers (1951) - Hubie & Bertie over indulge in a cheese factory. Thinking there is no reason to live, they want Claude Cat to eat them. (also on the Golden Collection 2 DVD)BONUS DOCUMENTARY: "Of Mice And Pen"Storyboards for The Hypo-Chrondri-CatCommentaries on "The Aristo-Cat" by Chick Jones, Greg Ford, Eddie Fitzgerald, "Mouse Wreckers" by Greg Ford, "The Hypo-Chrondri-Cat" by Jerry Beck.****Update****More Mice - 11 un-restored bonus cartoons (the quality varies quite a bit on these) in STANDARD DEFINITION. Most of these are NOT Chuck Jones cartoons. Some of these are RARELY seen on TV.After production work for this set was completed, WBHV decided to expand the set with some un-restored cartoons using the best video they had on hand. The earliest of these are rough and make you appreciate the work that went into restoring the above cartoons. From 1940 on the cartoons seem to be in pretty good shape and need little further restoration.Country Mouse (1935) a 2-strip technicolor cartoon with limited colors.The Lyin' Mouse (1937)The Mice Will Play (1938)Little Blabbermouse (1940) Note the altered copyright notice! This was a very talkative version of Sniffles, a characteristic Sniffles would take on in his later cartoons.Shop Look & Listen (1940) *Original Titles*  with W.C. Squeals & Blabbermouse.Mouse Mazurka (1948) with Sylvester the cat.Mouse-Warming (1951) with Claude Cat (from the Hubie & Bertie series).Mouse-Taken Identity (1957) *Original Titles* with Sylvester, his son Junior, & Hippity Hopper (who is always mistaken as a large mouse). Contrary to other reports, there IS a mouse in this cartoon.Mice Follies (1959) *Original Titles* In a spoof of the TV series THE HONEYMOONERS, Ralph & Morton stay out too late and try to sneak past the act to get home.It's Nice To Have A Mouse Around The House (1964) DePatie-Freling Production starring Speedy Gonzalas, Daffy Duck, Sylvester the cat, and Granny.Merlin The Magic Mouse (1967) A Warner Bros.-Seven Arts Production starring Merlin, a W.C. Fields mouse who is a magician.These would have been better as part of a 4-disc Golden Collection to round out the cuteness with Looney Tunes Humor.This will not be a collection you will watch in one sitting, the cartoons are just too similar.This collection will be more of one that you will sample from time to time when you have a few minutes to kill.If you watched these on TV, most of them were a part of the old "aap productions" syndication package. They were also included in the Turner Entertainment Laserdiscs and VHS tapes.These new transfers will out do those old presentations. These cartoons are getting the same restoration treatment that all of the other Platinum and Golden collections got.Original 35mm Nitrate YCM negatives are being used to master the Hi-Definition video transfers.While color balance & image sharpness will be spectacular. Warner does not go the route of Disney by scrubbing the images of all original defects, so you will see occasional white specs from dust on the animation cells just as they were always seen at the theaters.The old Laserdiscs & VHS tapes from Turner Home Video used 1957 35mm safety film release prints that were two generations away from the original YCM Nitrate negatives used here. Turner did not have access to the master Nitrate material.None of these will be letterboxed as they were made before 1954. Studios only consider letterboxing movies made from 1954 on, as most Hollywood theaters screened them that way. This issue never came up during the preparation of this disc set.
summary: No Bugs Bunny here, it is the complete SNIFFLES and HUBIE & BERTIE cartoon collection!

reviewText: Excuse me, but I don't see the great improvement Blu-Ray is supposed to give these cartoons. In fact, it seems to illuminate their flaws. Maybe my settings aren't right, but I see a lot of grain and I'm not getting the almost glass like quality I see on some HDTV broadcasts of older material. It makes me suspicious that they're not remastering these in HD, but simply throwing them onto the Blu-Ray format without proper restoration. I did a comparison and watched some cartoons from my Looney Tunes Golden Collections and they looked as good, and sometimes better, than my Blu-Ray Mouse Chronicles.That being said, I love finally having the Sniffles cartoons I've wanted all these years, and I love the Hubie and Berty cartoons as well. Thank you. I feel like they won't make a dime on these and that I'm lucky to get them before they realized they were a bad business investment for them, but a great acquisition for me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Always been a big fan of the Chuck Jones Hubie and Bertie cartoons, which are seldom seen anywhere. The two mice are really unique creations, always scampering on the periphery of late 40s/early 50s Warner Bros. animation. I'm sure he had real fondness for them, although their output never challenged the big honchos at the studio, Bugs, Daffy or the Road Runner. But the films of these little rodent scamps are truly funny... something you can't always say about the output of the others. That's because there were only a handful of the H&Bs and a seemingly million of those other star vehicles.  So, having all of them in a blu ray disc is a real treat. But, they also featured a lot of other Jones mouse cartoons, including all of the Sniffles collection and a smattering of others. There are one each  of the Jack Benny imitations and Honeymooner parodies. I seem to remember others in both of those series, but they don't appear. Were they not all Chuck Jones?  Odd they'd not include them. But what's here is beautifully presented
summary: Hubie and Bertie finally get their day!
